questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for the lesion developed by a patient after 6 months of undergoing heart surgery, as depicted below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Keloid scar Explanation: The most probable diagnosis based on the image and the lesion that developed 6 months after heart surgery is a keloid scar . It is characterized by abnormal and excessive growth of scar tissue that grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress. It typically appears firm, raised, and extends beyond the margins of the initial injury. Keloid formation seems to be an individual predisposition, and it is more common in African Americans. Sternum is the most common site for Keloid formation. Treatment can be done by i ntralesional injection of steroids like Triamcinolone. Hypertrophic scars (Option A) are also raised, they typically remain within the boundaries of the original injury. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after treatment compared to keloids. Atrophic scars (Option B) are pale, flat, and depressed scars that appear sunken or as indentations in the skin due to loss of tissue or collagen. Contracture (Option D) occurs when scar tissue forms and tightens , leading to restricted movement of nearby joints or tissues. They typically occur in case of burns or deep wounds . Contractures may result in deformity and functional impairment.

questions.question: A 23-year-old man presented with a burn injury. He is covered with burns on his head & neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 45% Explanation: The correct answer in the given condition is 45% based on the rule of 9. To calculate the percentage of burns , we can use the Rule of Nines , a system commonly used to estimate the body surface area (BSA) affected by burns. Since the patient in the scenario is an adult, Burned area% = Head & neck (9%) + Both upper limbs (18%) + Front & back of the chest (18%) = 45% Rule of Nines Adults Children Infants Head & neck 9% 18% 20% Front of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Back of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Lower limb 18 x 2 = 36% 13.5 x 2 = 27% 10 x 2 = 20% Upper limb 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Perineum 1% 1% Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 122

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding Marjolin’s ulcer is not true?

options.A: It is seen in sites of chronic wounds or scars
options.C: It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
options.D: It is radioresistant due to avascularity

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) It rapidly progresses to malignancy Explanation: A marjolin’s ulcer usually occurs on long-standing chronic wound scars. It presents as a non-healing ulcer with elevated margins that grow rapidly. In some cases, it can become malignant and progress to squamous cell carcinoma. It is usually treated by surgical excision using Mohs surgery, where the lesion, along with a 1-2 cm margin is removed. It is seen in the site of chronic wounds or scars (Option A). This statement regarding Marjolin’s ulcer is true. It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma (Option C) It has a greater chance of progressing to squamous cell carcinoma rather than basal cell carcinoma. It is radioresistant due to avascularity (Option D). This statement is also true as Marjolin’s ulcer has less vascularity and can be radioresistant. Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 283, 284 Pubmed

questions.question: A 65-year-old man who has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Basal cell carcinoma Explanation: Basal cell carcinoma, a slow-growing malignant tumor, invades locally and primarily affects the pilosebaceous skin. It's mainly categorised into localized and generalized forms, with nodular and nodulocystic variants comprising 90% of cases. Typically, it appears as a pink, pearly papule with telangiectasias, rolled borders, and central crusty ulcerations. Dermatofibrosarcoma (Option A) It is a soft tissue sarcoma that presents as a reddish-brown plaque that does not have rolled borders as seen in the image. Marjolin’s ulcer (Option B) Marjolin’s ulcer can develop into squamous cell carcinoma. It occurs on a previously long-standing scar. The image shown is not marjolin’s ulcer. Nevus (Option D) It is a benign skin growth that occurs due to the accumulation of melanocytes. The image shown is not a nevus. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 284-286

questions.question: Pressure greater than __ mm of Hg causes pressure sores.:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 33 Explanation: Pressure sores (also called decubitus ulcers or pressure ulcers ) occur due to prolonged pressure on the skin , leading to ischemia and tissue necrosis . The critical pressure threshold that exceeds capillary perfusion pressure and causes ischemia is greater than 33 mmHg . Normal capillary pressure is around 25–32 mmHg , so pressure exceeding 33 mmHg leads to inadequate blood supply and tissue damage. 45 mmHg, 54 mmHg, 67 mmHg (Option B, C and D) While higher pressures can accelerate tissue necrosis, ischemia begins at pressures just above 33 mmHg. Higher pressures are often seen in bony prominences (e.g., sacrum, heels), but even lower sustained pressure over time can lead to ulcers. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 325, 326

questions.question: What is the preferred management of angular dermoid cyst?

options.C: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision Explanation : Angular dermoid is a type of dermoid cyst that commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture. The formation of an angular dermoid is due to the sequestration of ectodermal tissue during embryonic development, which gives rise to a cyst containing dermal elements like hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and sweat glands. Angular dermoids are most often located near the lateral canthus , which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet. They may also occur near suture lines of the skull. They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected. Diagnosis and Treatment: Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected. Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice , especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms. Careful dissection is required to ensure that the cyst is fully removed and to avoid recurrence. If left untreated, angular dermoids sometimes undergo resorption or indentation of the underlying base. CT is done to rule out dural attachments. Wait and watch (Option B) This is not recommended for angular dermoids, as they can grow or become infected. Surgical excision is the definitive treatment. Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin (Option C) A wide excision is unnecessary. Angular dermoids are benign, so simple surgical excision without wide margins is sufficient. Laser ablation (Option D) is inappropriate for treating angular dermoids. Surgical excision ensures complete removal of the cyst, preventing recurrence. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 72

questions.question: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks ago now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Hypertrophic scar Explanation: Comparison of Hypertrophic Scar, Keloid, Exuberant Granulation, and Granulation Tissue Feature Hypertrophic Scar Keloid Exuberant Granulation ("Proud Flesh") Granulation Tissue Definition Excess collagen deposition leading to a raised scar within wound boundaries. (Option D ruled out ) Excess collagen deposition extending beyond the wound. (Option A ruled out ) Overgrowth of granulation tissue above skin level. (Option B ruled out ) Early vascularized tissue forming during wound healing. (Option C) Wound Boundaries Confined to the original wound. Extends beyond the wound margins. Protrudes beyond the skin level. Confined to wound, but not raised. Onset Weeks after injury. Months after injury. Early post-injury phase. Forms within days of injury. Resolution May regress over time. Persists and grows continuously. Requires treatment (cauterization or excision). Normal component of healing. Common Locations Areas of high tension (joints, chest, back). Earlobes, shoulders, chest, upper arms. Open wounds, surgical sites. Any healing wound. Histology Collagen organized parallel to skin surface. Disorganized, excessive collagen deposition. Excess granulation tissue, rich in capillaries. Fibroblasts, capillaries, and inflammatory cells. Treatment Pressure therapy, steroids, laser therapy (if symptomatic). Intralesional steroids, cryotherapy, excision (high recurrence). Silver nitrate cautery, surgical trimming. No treatment needed (normal part of healing). Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 24, 25, 684, 685

questions.question: In the case of a woman who has suffered third and fourth degree burns on her back, what would be the appropriate sequence of steps in her treatment?
questions.explanation: while fourth-degree burns extend into the muscle, bone, or internal organs. Both types of burns require prompt and aggressive treatment to prevent complications such as infection, hypovolemia, and shock. The most appropriate order of sequence in the management of a woman who has sustained third and fourth-degree burns on her back is as follows: Resuscitation: The first step in the management of severe burns is resuscitation. This involves assessing and stabilizing the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Intravenous fluids and electrolytes are administered to prevent hypovolemia and maintain hemodynamic stability. Debridement: Once the patient is stabilized, the next step is debridement. Debridement involves removing all necrotic tissue and debris from the wound to prevent infection and promote healing. Surgical or non-surgical methods can do debridement. Allograft or autograft: After debridement, the wound is covered with either an allograft or autograft. Allografts are skin grafts taken from another person, while autografts are skin grafts taken from the patient's own body. Both types of grafts can provide temporary coverage to the wound and promote wound healing. Therefore, the correct option would be Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft. Incorrect Choices: Option a. Resuscitation – reconstruction – debridement is incorrect because Ressuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence. Option c: Debridement – resuscitation – autograft is incorrect because Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence. Option d: Reconstruction is not an appropriate step in the initial management of third and fourth-degree burns, as the focus should be on stabilizing the patient and preventing complications. Reconstruction is typically done later in the treatment process once the wound has healed. Thus, Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence. Reference: .

questions.question: What type of graft is used when a patient undergoes skin grafting following a road traffic accident in which the graft is harvested from the patient's own body?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Autograft Explanation: The graft harvested from the patient's own body is called an autograft. Compatibility: Better immune compatibility; lower risk of hyperacute rejection. Example: Primate to human (e.g., baboon to human). Discordant Xenograft: Xenograft between distantly related species. Compatibility: Poor immune compatibility; high risk of hyperacute rejection. Example: Pig to human. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 688. questions.question: What type of dressing is used to cover this post burn wound?
questions.explanation: transplanting the top layers of skin (epidermis and part of the dermis) from a donor site to cover a post-burn wound. After the graft is applied, dressings are used to secure it, promote adherence, and protect the wound. The graft itself is the primary coverage for the wound. Incorrect Options: Option B - Full Thickness Skin Graft : This option refers to a different type of graft where both the epidermis and the entire dermis are transplanted. Full-thickness grafts are used for smaller wounds requiring greater durability and better cosmetic outcomes. However, they are not typically used for extensive post-burn wound coverage. Option C - VAC Dressing : Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing is used to promote healing in complex wounds by applying negative pressure. It’s often used for deep or chronic wounds but is not the primary method for covering a fresh skin graft. Option D - Normal Sumag Dressing: While normal dressings may be used as secondary coverage to protect the graft site, they are not the primary method for securing a grafted area.

questions.question: What is the specific instrument utilized for extracting the graft from the healthy region during split thickness skin grafting ?
questions.explanation: specialized instrument used for skin grafting. It is specifically designed to harvest thin slices of skin, making it suitable for split-thickness skin grafting procedures. The Humby knife allows controlled removal of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis from the donor site. Incorrect Options: Option A - Dermatome: A dermatome is the correct instrument used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts. It is a surgical instrument specifically designed for this purpose. The dermatome allows controlled and precise removal of the epidermis and a variable thickness of the dermis from the healthy donor area. The harvested graft is then transferred to the recipient site, where it is secured and allowed to heal. Option B - Silver's knife: Silver's knife, also known as a razor or scalpel, is a general surgical instrument used for various purposes, including making incisions and excisions. While a scalpel may be used during certain steps of the split-thickness skin grafting procedure, it is not the primary instrument for graft harvesting. Option C - Catlin amputating knife: Catlin amputating knife is a type of surgical instrument used for amputations or limb removal. It is not typically used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts, as its design and purpose are different.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar ?

options.A: The extant does not cross the wound margins
options.B: Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
options.C: Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
options.D: A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.explanation: from an overactive healing response to an injury. A keloid scar develops from heightened levels of growth factors, resulting in excessive tissue formation beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often leading to raised, thickened scar tissue. Incorrect Options; Option A - The extent of a keloid scar can cross the wound margins: Keloid scars are characterized by their tendency to extend beyond the original wound boundaries. Unlike normal scars, which typically stay within the limits of the wound, keloids can grow and spread beyond the initial injury site. Option B - Wide excision of a keloid scar does not necessarily prevent recurrence: Keloid scars have a high recurrence rate even after surgical removal. While excision may temporarily remove the keloid, it does not guarantee that it won't reappear. Keloids have a complex and poorly understood formation process involving various factors, and surgical removal alone may not address all underlying causes. Option C - Histopathology of a keloid scar does not typically show reduced collagen and increased vascularity: Keloid scars are characterized by excessive collagen deposition, leading to the formation of raised, firm, and thickened scars. The histopathological examination of keloids typically reveals an abundance of collagen fibers in irregular arrangements. Increased vascularity is not a consistent finding in keloids. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most suitable graft for performing a femoropopliteal bypass procedure?
questions.explanation: femoropopliteal bypass due to its superior long-term patency rates and overall success in these procedures. Incorrect Options: Option A - Dacron: Dacron, a synthetic graft, is a secondary choice for femoropopliteal bypass due to lower patency rates compared to the great saphenous vein. Option C - Polytetrafluoroethylene: Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), another synthetic graft, has inferior long-term patency rates to the great saphenous vein for femoropopliteal bypass. Option D - Short saphenous vein: The short saphenous vein is less favored than the great saphenous vein for femoropopliteal bypass due to its smaller diameter and inferior long-term outcomes. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the primary concern in managing hand injuries ?
questions.explanation: hand. If there is a significant tendon injury, such as a complete tendon laceration or avulsion, restoring the continuity and function of the tendons becomes a top priority. Tendon repair is important to regain proper hand function and dexterity. In some cases, delayed or inadequate tendon repair can result in long-term impairment of hand movement. Incorrect Options: Option B - Repair of skin cover: Skin cover refers to the integrity and closure of the skin over the injured area. Skin closure is important to prevent infection, promote wound healing, and provide a protective barrier. Depending on the severity of the hand injury, the need for skin repair or closure may vary. Superficial lacerations or abrasions may require simple wound cleaning and closure, while more complex injuries may necessitate complex wound reconstruction or grafting. Option C - Repair of nerves : Nerve injuries in the hand can result in sensory loss, motor deficits, and impaired hand function. Nerve repair or reconstruction is crucial in cases of significant nerve injury, such as complete transection or severe compression. The restoration of nerve function can help regain sensation, muscle control, and coordination in the hand. However, the prioritization of nerve repair may depend on the overall severity and complexity of the hand injury. Option D - All: It is incorrect as tendon repair is the most important factor in the repair of hand injuries. Reference: Prepladder Notes

Despite undergoing surgery to remove the lesion, it consistently returns after the procedure. During the examination, the patient has a painless swelling measuring 2 cm in front of his tragus. questions.question: Rodent ulcer is:
questions.explanation: common type of skin cancer that arises from basal cells in the skin. Rodent ulcer, also referred to as tear cancer, is characterized by local invasiveness, resulting in the destruction of surrounding tissues, typically seen on the face above the line connecting the ear lobule to the angle or corner of the mouth. Emerging from the basal layer of the epidermis, it most frequently occurs on the nose, with inner canthus being another common site. Incorrect Options: Option A - Squamous cell cancer: Squamous cell cancer, also known as squamous cell carcinoma, is a type of skin cancer that arises from squamous cells. It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat lesion with a scaly or crusty surface. While squamous cell carcinoma is a common type of skin cancer, it is not specifically associated with the term "Rodent ulcer." Option C - Rhinophyma: Rhinophyma is a condition characterized by the thickening and enlargement of the nose, often resulting in a bulbous or irregular appearance. It is typically associated with severe forms of rosacea and is not related to "Rodent ulcer," which specifically refers to a type of skin cancer. Option D - Adenocarcinoma : Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that originates in glandular cells. It can occur in various organs, such as the lung, colon, breast, and prostate. However, it is not associated with the term "Rodent ulcer," which specifically refers to a type of skin cancer. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A lady with 50% TBSA burn + involvement of dermis & subcutaneous tissue came to the emergency department. Which degree burn is this:
questions.explanation: the complete destruction of the epidermis and dermis and extends into the subcutaneous tissue. It typically appears as a white or charred area and is often painless due to the destruction of nerve endings. In the given scenario, with 50% total body surface area (TBSA) involvement and the inclusion of dermis and subcutaneous tissue, it is classified as a third-degree burn. Incorrect Options: Option A - 1 st degree: A first-degree burn, also known as a superficial burn, only affects the outermost layer of the skin, the epidermis . Option B - 2 nd degree superficial : A 2 nd -degree superficial burn, also called a partial-thickness burn, involves both the epidermis and a portion of the underlying dermis . Option C - 2 nd degree deep: A 2 nd -degree deep burn, also a partial-thickness burn, affects the epidermis and extends deeper into the dermis , involving the deeper layers of the skin. It often presents with redness, pain, blistering, and severe swelling. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Cellulitis is:
questions.explanation: inflammation of the skin and underlying tissues. Cellulitis is considered suppurative because it often involves the formation of pus, which consists of dead white blood cells, bacteria, and tissue debris. It is invasive because the bacterial infection penetrates and spreads through the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, causing inflammation and damage beyond the surface layer. This invasion can lead to significant tissue destruction and systemic complications if not promptly treated with antibiotics and proper wound care. Incorrect Options: Option A - Nonsuppurative & Noninvasive: Stating cellulitis as nonsuppurative and noninvasive, is incorrect. Cellulitis is typically associated with the presence of pus (suppuration) due to bacterial infection, and it can involve deeper layers of the skin and tissues (invasive). Option B - Nonsuppurative & invasive: Stating cellulitis as nonsuppurative and invasive, is also incorrect. While cellulitis can be invasive, it is commonly associated with the presence of pus (suppuration) as bacteria invade and cause an inflammatory response in the affected area. Option C - Suprative & Noninvasive: Stating cellulitis as suppurative and noninvasive, is incorrect as well. Cellulitis often involves the production of pus (suppuration) due to bacterial infection, and it can extend into deeper tissues (invasive). Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What does the inclusion of a split-thickness skin graft in wound closure on the thigh entail?

options.B: Epidermis and variable part of the dermis

questions.explanation: involves taking a graft that includes the epidermis and a variable portion of the dermis. This type of graft allows for a larger area of skin to be harvested compared to full-thickness grafts, which take the entire thickness of the skin. Common donor sites for STSG include the inner aspect of the thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall. Incorrect Options: Option A, C and D : Refer to the explanation of correct option. Reference: Prepladder Notes
